item.title: Many Adults Don't Think Exposure To Vaping Is Bad For Kids
item.description: May 25, 2017 - Nicotine, heavy metals and tiny particles that can harm the lungs float around in the aerosol from e-cigarettes. But a survey finds many adults don't think secondhand vape is dangerous for children.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 25, 2017 - Nicotine, heavy metals and tiny particles that can harm the lungs float around in the aerosol from e-cigarettes. But a survey finds many adults don't think secondhand vape is dangerous for children. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/25/530026958/many-adults-dont-think-exposure-to-vaping-is-bad-for-kids

item.title: Patient, Doctor Groups Say New CBO Score Reveals Health Care Bill's Flaws
item.description: May 25, 2017 - The latest analysis by the Congressional Budget Office says the bill would lead to 23 million fewer people having insurance coverage and would cut the federal deficit by $119 billion over 10 years.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 25, 2017 - The latest analysis by the Congressional Budget Office says the bill would lead to 23 million fewer people having insurance coverage and would cut the federal deficit by $119 billion over 10 years. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/25/529909663/patient-doctor-groups-say-new-cbo-score-reveals-health-bills-flaws

item.title: Eating Chocolate, A Little Each Week, May Lower The Risk Of A Heart Flutter
item.description: May 24, 2017 - The latest evidence that a chocolate habit may lower your risk of heart disease: A study finds people who ate small amounts of chocolate several times a week had a lower risk of atrial fibrillation.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - The latest evidence that a chocolate habit may lower your risk of heart disease: A study finds people who ate small amounts of chocolate several times a week had a lower risk of atrial fibrillation. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/05/24/529843647/eating-chocolate-a-little-each-week-may-lower-the-risk-of-a-heart-flutter

item.title: Trump Wants Families On Food Stamps To Get Jobs. The Majority Already Work
item.description: May 24, 2017 - Some 55 percent of families with kids on SNAP have jobs — they just don't earn enough to live on. Many states where reliance on SNAP is heaviest voted overwhelmingly for Trump last November.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - Some 55 percent of families with kids on SNAP have jobs — they just don't earn enough to live on. Many states where reliance on SNAP is heaviest voted overwhelmingly for Trump last November. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/05/24/529831472/trump-wants-families-on-food-stamps-to-get-jobs-the-majority-already-work

item.title: CBO Releases Score For House-Approved American Health Care Act
item.description: May 24, 2017 - The Congressional Budget Office gave its projections Wednesday on the costs and impact of the version of the American Health Care Act passed by the House earlier this month.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - The Congressional Budget Office gave its projections Wednesday on the costs and impact of the version of the American Health Care Act passed by the House earlier this month. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/24/529893114/cbo-releases-score-for-house-approved-american-health-care-act

item.title: GOP Health Plan Would Leave 23 Million More Uninsured, Budget Office Says
item.description: May 24, 2017 - The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office estimates that the Republicans' Obamacare repeal-and-replace bill would also reduce the deficit and leave some sick Americans unable to buy coverage.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office estimates that the Republicans' Obamacare repeal-and-replace bill would also reduce the deficit and leave some sick Americans unable to buy coverage. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/24/529902300/cbo-republicans-ahca-would-leave-23-million-more-uninsured

item.title: Scientists Develop New Treatment Strategies For Child Psychopaths
item.description: May 24, 2017 - NPR's Audie Cornish speaks with writer Barbara Bradley Hagerty about her piece in The Atlantic on the children who are psychopaths, new treatment strategies and the brain science driving it.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - NPR's Audie Cornish speaks with writer Barbara Bradley Hagerty about her piece in The Atlantic on the children who are psychopaths, new treatment strategies and the brain science driving it. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/24/529893128/scientists-develop-new-treatment-strategies-for-child-psychopaths

item.title: Health Care Industry Anticipates CBO Score For House-Approved Bill
item.description: May 24, 2017 - NPR's Audie Cornish speaks with Caroline Pearson, senior vice president of Avalere Health, about what the new CBO score for the American Health Care Act means for reconciliation with the Senate.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - NPR's Audie Cornish speaks with Caroline Pearson, senior vice president of Avalere Health, about what the new CBO score for the American Health Care Act means for reconciliation with the Senate. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/24/529893088/health-care-industry-anticipates-cbo-score-for-house-approved-bill

item.title: Fitness Trackers: Good at Measuring Heart Rate, Not So Good At Measuring Calories
item.description: May 24, 2017 - A study of seven popular fitness trackers found they are generally good at measuring heart rate, but may mislead consumers about how many calories they have burned.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - A study of seven popular fitness trackers found they are generally good at measuring heart rate, but may mislead consumers about how many calories they have burned. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/24/529839681/fitness-trackers-good-at-measuring-heart-rate-not-so-good-at-measuring-calories

item.title: Miami's Zika Outbreak Began Months Before It Was First Detected
item.description: May 24, 2017 - Travelers infected with the Zika virus in the Caribbean brought it to South Florida multiple times before officials realized it had reached the U.S., an analysis of virus genomes finds.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - Travelers infected with the Zika virus in the Caribbean brought it to South Florida multiple times before officials realized it had reached the U.S., an analysis of virus genomes finds. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/24/529721114/miamis-zika-outbreak-began-months-before-it-was-first-detected

item.title: Doctors Once Thought Bananas Cured Celiac Disease. They Saved Kids' Lives — At A Cost
item.description: May 24, 2017 - In the early 20th century, kids with the disease faced severe malnutrition, even death. The banana-based diet doctors came up with seemed to cure them — but led kids back to foods that made them sick.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - In the early 20th century, kids with the disease faced severe malnutrition, even death. The banana-based diet doctors came up with seemed to cure them — but led kids back to foods that made them sick. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/05/24/529527564/doctors-once-thought-bananas-cured-celiac-disease-it-saved-kids-lives-at-a-cost

item.title: World Health Organization Elects First Director-General From Africa
item.description: May 23, 2017 - The new leader, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus of Ethiopia, will be expected to reform the bureaucratic agency and deal with the world's growing health problems.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 23, 2017 - The new leader, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus of Ethiopia, will be expected to reform the bureaucratic agency and deal with the world's growing health problems. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/05/23/529712013/world-health-organization-elects-first-director-general-from-africa

item.title: 43 Percent Of Children Who Died From Car Crashes Were Improperly Restrained
item.description: May 23, 2017 - A review of child deaths after fatal car crashes found wide variations by state and region, and suggests state authorities could radically decrease child deaths by changing traffic safety laws.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 23, 2017 - A review of child deaths after fatal car crashes found wide variations by state and region, and suggests state authorities could radically decrease child deaths by changing traffic safety laws. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/23/529685650/study-finds-43-percent-of-children-killed-in-car-crashes-were-improperly-restrai

item.title: 'Smile Stealers' Recalls A Time When Dentists Routinely Reached For The Pliers
item.description: May 23, 2017 - Medical historian Richard Barnett traces the history of dentistry in his new book. He says that prior to the 18th century, the profession was often practiced by charlatans with "big muscles."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 23, 2017 - Medical historian Richard Barnett traces the history of dentistry in his new book. He says that prior to the 18th century, the profession was often practiced by charlatans with "big muscles." http://www.npr.org/2017/05/23/529671017/smile-stealers-recalls-a-time-when-dentists-routinely-reached-for-the-pliers

item.title: Medical Research, Health Care Face Deep Cuts In Trump Budget
item.description: May 23, 2017 - The administration's proposed budget would cut billions out of health programs at the NIH, CDC and FDA, as well as Medicaid services for children, the elderly and disabled.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 23, 2017 - The administration's proposed budget would cut billions out of health programs at the NIH, CDC and FDA, as well as Medicaid services for children, the elderly and disabled. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/23/529654114/medical-research-health-care-face-deep-cuts-in-trump-budget
